content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Nathan Meyer: I was born in Zurich, Switzerland, to a family that valued education and cultural heritage. My parents were both academics—my father a historian and my mother a linguist—so growing up, books and languages were always around me. We moved to the United States when I was about ten, settling in Evanston, Illinois, where I've lived ever since. It was a big adjustment at first, especially learning English, but I was lucky to have a strong support system. My parents made sure I felt connected to my roots, and I still speak fluent German and Hebrew today. I went to a public high school here, and though I struggled a bit with the cultural shift, I found my passion for social sciences and policy during my undergraduate studies at the University of Chicago. I eventually pursued a graduate degree in public policy, which led me to my current role working with non-profits focused on immigrant integration and social equity. I've never married, and I've always been more focused on my career and community work than on personal relationships. My Jewish faith has been a constant in my life, shaping my values and how I approach the world. I'm proud to be a U.S. citizen now, and I've always felt that my background—being both Swiss and American—has given me a unique perspective on issues like identity, belonging, and the importance of inclusive policies.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Nathan Meyer: Yes, there was a defining moment that shaped the course of my life. It happened during my sophomore year of high school, when I was struggling to find my place in the new culture here. I was still adjusting to life in the U.S., and I felt like an outsider in many ways—both because of my accent and because I didn't always understand the social norms. One day, I was walking home from school when I saw a group of kids from my school organizing a community clean-up in a local park. I hesitated at first, unsure if I belonged there, but I decided to join them. That day, I met a teacher named Ms. Alvarez, who was volunteering with the group. She noticed my hesitation and asked me why I was there. I told her I felt like I didn't fit in, and she said something that stuck with me: 'You don't have to fit in to belong. You just have to be willing to try.' That conversation changed my perspective. I started volunteering more, joined the debate team, and slowly began to feel more connected to my school and community. That experience opened my eyes to the power of community engagement and the importance of creating spaces where people feel seen and heard. It was the moment I realized I wanted to work in social policy—helping others find their place in the world, just like she helped me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Nathan Meyer: I think, in that moment, it was a conscious choice—though not one I made with full clarity at the time. I was aware that I had a choice: to keep isolating myself or to take a step toward something different. But what made it a choice I could live with was the support I received from people like Ms. Alvarez. She didn't just offer words; she offered a path. I think what made it feel like a decision I could make was that I realized I had the agency to shape my own experience, even in a place that felt so foreign to me. It wasn't just about fitting in—it was about finding a way to be myself while also being part of something bigger. That realization was the first step in understanding that my identity wasn't fixed, and that I could choose to build a life that honored both my roots and my new home.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Nathan Meyer: Absolutely. In fact, I think the support I received from my parents was just as crucial. They never treated my struggle with adjustment as a failure on my part. Instead, they encouraged me to explore my interests and connect with others who shared them. My father, for instance, helped me understand that feeling out of place was a common experience for immigrants and that it didn't define my worth. My mother, on the other hand, introduced me to local cultural groups where I could practice my language skills and meet people who had similar backgrounds. Without their guidance and the kindness of people like Ms. Alvarez, I might have remained isolated. I think it's important to recognize that no one has to navigate life's challenges alone—there are always people or organizations willing to help, as long as you're open to reaching out.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Nathan Meyer: I don't have a partner or children at the moment. My life has been pretty focused on my work and community involvement, and I've always found that my energy is better spent on causes I care about than on personal relationships. That said, I have a close-knit family—my parents still live in Evanston, and we stay in touch regularly. My father recently retired from his university position, and he's been spending more time traveling, which has been a nice way for us to reconnect. My mother still works part-time as a consultant in linguistics, and she's always been a source of wisdom and support for me. I also have a younger sister who moved to Tel Aviv a few years ago. She's a graphic designer, and though we don't see each other as often as I'd like, we keep in touch through video calls and shared family traditions. My Jewish heritage is something I hold close, and I make sure to celebrate holidays with my family whenever possible. While I haven't prioritized a romantic relationship, I don't see it as a lack of interest—it's more about timing and finding someone who shares my values and passion for making a difference in the world.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by moments of uncertainty, support, and conscious choices. From my early years in Zurich to adjusting to life in the U.S., my story has always been about finding a place where I belong—not just geographically, but emotionally and culturally. The crossroads I faced in high school with Ms. Alvarez's words still resonate with me today, reminding me that belonging is not about fitting in, but about being willing to try. My parents' unwavering support and the kindness of others helped me navigate those early challenges, and that experience ultimately led me to the path I'm on now—working in social policy and immigrant integration. While I may not have a family in the traditional sense, the relationships I've built and the values I hold dear are just as meaningful. I've come to understand that my identity is a blend of my Swiss and American roots, my Jewish heritage, and the experiences that have shaped me along the way. It's a life I've chosen, step by step, with the help of those who believed in me even when I didn't believe in myself.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Nathan Meyer: My immediate family includes my grandparents on both my father's and mother's sides, though I haven't spoken to my maternal grandparents as much in recent years. My father's family is quite close-knit—my paternal grandfather passed away a few years ago, but my grandmother still lives in Zurich, and we visit her whenever we can. She's the one who taught me how to cook traditional Swiss dishes, and I still make her famous apple strudel for holidays. My mother's family is more spread out; her parents moved to Israel many years ago, and while I respect their decision, I've never felt as connected to them as I do to my father's side. That said, I do keep in touch with my maternal uncle, who lives in Boston. He's a musician, and we've had some interesting conversations about identity and culture over the years. He's always been a good reminder that even within the same family, people can have very different experiences and perspectives. I think that's something I carry with me in my work—recognizing that everyone's journey is unique, and that understanding those differences is key to building a more inclusive society.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Nathan Meyer: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Alex, a fellow policy advocate I met during my graduate studies. We've been working together on several immigrant integration projects, and he's become like a brother to me. He's the one who always pushes me to think more critically about the policies we support and reminds me that our work has real, human consequences. Then there's Rachel, a community organizer I admire deeply. She's been a mentor to me in many ways, showing me how to build trust with people from diverse backgrounds. I've learned so much from her about listening and empathy. I also have a few close friends from my volunteer days in high school—people like Marcus, who's now a teacher, and Lena, who works in social work. We still get together for coffee or holidays, and those connections have been a source of comfort and inspiration. While I don't have a romantic partner, I feel deeply connected to the people I work with and the communities I serve. They've helped shape who I am, just as my family and early experiences did.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Nathan Meyer: I live in a neighborhood in Evanston that feels like a small city within a city. It's a mix of old and new—there are historic homes with large porches and well-kept gardens, but also modern apartments and co-living spaces that cater to students and young professionals. The streets are lined with trees, and there's a strong sense of community here. I live in a two-bedroom apartment near the downtown area, which is walkable to cafes, bookstores, and the local library. One of the things I love most about Evanston is its cultural diversity. There are a lot of immigrants and international students here, which makes the atmosphere feel dynamic and ever-changing. I often run into people from different backgrounds at the local coffee shop or during community events, and that reminds me of why I chose this field in the first place. The neighborhood also has a strong arts scene, with galleries and theaters that host performances in multiple languages—something I really appreciate as someone who speaks more than one language. It's not perfect, of course; like any city, there are challenges with housing costs and gentrification, but overall, I feel like I'm in a place that values inclusion and intellectual curiosity. It's a place where I can be both rooted and open to new experiences, which is something I think is really important in life.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Nathan Meyer: I feel quite safe in Evanston, though I think it's more about the sense of community than just physical safety. There's a lot of foot traffic in the downtown area, and people seem to look out for one another. I've never felt threatened or unwelcome here, which is something I really appreciate. That sense of belonging is part of why I chose to stay in Evanston after moving here as a child. It's not just a place to live—it's a place where I can be myself, where my Swiss and American identities coexist without conflict. I know that not everyone feels safe in their neighborhoods, and that's something I'm always mindful of in my work. It's one of the reasons I focus on immigrant integration and community building—because I've seen firsthand how a supportive environment can make all the difference in someone's life.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Nathan Meyer: Living here has had its challenges, of course. The cost of living has gone up significantly over the years, and I've had to make some tough decisions about where to allocate my resources. I've always prioritized my work and community involvement, so I've had to be careful with my budget. That said, the upside is that Evanston has a lot to offer in terms of culture, education, and opportunities for engagement. I've been able to build a life that aligns with my values—supporting causes I care about, staying connected to my roots, and being part of a community that feels inclusive. There are days when I feel the weight of it all, especially when I think about how much has changed since I first arrived here as a child. But overall, I'm grateful for the stability and the people who make this place feel like home. It's not without its struggles, but I've learned to find meaning in the small moments—the conversations at the coffee shop, the laughter with friends, the sense of purpose in my work. That's what keeps me going.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my sense of belonging and safety in Evanston has shaped my perspective on community and identity. Discussing my family, friends, and neighborhood has reminded me of the importance of connection—not just to people, but to the places we call home. While I don't have a traditional family structure with a partner or children, the relationships I've built with my parents, siblings, and friends are deeply meaningful. They've been my anchor through the challenges of living in a place that, while not perfect, has always felt like a home. Talking about my neighborhood and feeling safe here has also reinforced why I chose to work in immigrant integration and social equity—because I know what it's like to feel like an outsider, and I want to help others find the sense of belonging I've come to value. It's not just about where you live, but how you feel in that space, and I'm grateful for the community that has supported me all these years.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Nathan Meyer: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there's always some flexibility depending on projects or community events. I usually start my week with a morning routine—coffee, a quick walk around the neighborhood, and checking my emails. Mondays are often the most intense, as that's when I meet with my team at the non-profit I work with. We're currently focused on a housing initiative for newly arrived immigrants, so I spend a lot of time coordinating with local organizations, attending meetings, and reviewing policy documents. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are a mix of meetings, research, and sometimes fieldwork. I love going out into the community to talk to people directly—whether it's at a local cultural center or a community kitchen. Thursdays are usually lighter, allowing me to catch up on reading or attend a workshop. I also try to set aside time for exercise, usually a run or a yoga class, which helps me stay grounded. Fridays are often the busiest in terms of outreach—sometimes I'm organizing events or giving talks at schools or libraries. On the weekends, I like to slow down. I might meet up with friends for brunch, visit my parents, or spend time in the library researching for upcoming projects. I also make sure to set aside a few hours each week for personal reflection—journaling, reading fiction, or just sitting in silence. It's a balance between being productive and being present, and I think that balance is what keeps me from feeling overwhelmed. Even though my work is demanding, I find that the connections I make and the impact I can have make it all worthwhile.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Nathan Meyer: I work full-time as a policy analyst for a non-profit organization based in Evanston called the Center for Community Integration. My days typically start around 8:30 a.m., and I work from Monday through Friday, though I often stay late on some evenings when I'm preparing reports or attending meetings. The organization focuses on immigrant integration, housing equity, and social policy reform, which aligns closely with my personal values and experiences. I especially enjoy the collaborative environment—we work closely with local government officials, community leaders, and grassroots organizations to develop programs that support marginalized groups. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is when I get to meet with individuals who have recently arrived in the U.S. and hear their stories. It reminds me of my own journey and reinforces why I chose this path. I also serve on a few advisory boards for local initiatives, which allows me to contribute to policy discussions in a more direct way. While the work can be demanding, I find it deeply fulfilling. It's not just about analyzing data or writing reports—it's about making a tangible difference in people's lives, and that's something I take very seriously.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Nathan Meyer: In addition to my work, I have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening, I try to spend at least an hour reading—whether it's non-fiction about social policy or fiction in Hebrew or German. It's a way for me to unwind and connect with the languages and cultures that shaped me. I also make it a point to cook at least one meal from scratch each week, often something from my Swiss heritage like fondue or raclette. It's not just about the food; it's about the memories and traditions that come with it. On weekends, I sometimes visit the Evanston Jewish Community Center, where I attend a weekly discussion group on global politics and culture. It's a space where I can engage with others who share my interests and background, and it's been a great source of intellectual and emotional support over the years. I also have a small garden on my balcony where I grow herbs and a few vegetables. Tending to it gives me a sense of peace, especially after long days of work. These routines, though simple, are important to me—they help me maintain a sense of balance and connection to who I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Nathan Meyer: In the past few months, I've started waking up a bit earlier than usual—around 7 a.m.—to give myself more time for reflection before the day begins. It's something I've been doing to counteract the stress of working on such emotionally heavy issues. I find that the quiet hours before the city wakes up are a good time to journal or meditate, which helps me center myself. I've also been more intentional about taking breaks during the workday, especially after long meetings or difficult conversations. I've started using those moments to walk through the neighborhood or call a friend for a quick chat. It's a small change, but it's made a noticeable difference in how I carry myself throughout the day. Another shift has been in how I approach weekends—I've been trying to unplug more, limiting my screen time and focusing on activities that nourish my mind and body, like visiting the local museum or attending a poetry reading at the community center. These changes aren't drastic, but they're helping me feel more present and balanced in my life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Nathan Meyer: I don't have children, but I often imagine what life would be like if I did. I think I'd want to raise them in a way that honors both my Swiss and American heritage, teaching them to value education, cultural curiosity, and social responsibility. I'd hope they'd grow up feeling comfortable with who they are, no matter where they come from or what challenges they face. I'd also want them to understand the importance of community and the power of small acts of kindness. While I haven't had the experience of parenting, I've seen it in others—like my friends and colleagues—and I admire the patience, love, and sacrifice it takes. I think it's one of the most meaningful ways to make a difference in the world, even if it's not a path I've taken myself.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are intertwined with the values and experiences that have shaped me over the years. From my work in immigrant integration to the small rituals that ground me—like reading, cooking, or tending to my garden—each part of my life reinforces the importance of connection, both to people and to the world around me. Discussing my neighborhood, my job, and my personal habits has reminded me that even in the busiest of days, there is value in slowing down and being present. It's not just about the work I do or the places I live—it's about how I choose to engage with life, and how those choices reflect the lessons I've learned from my family, my community, and the people I've met along the way. I feel grateful for the balance I've found, and I know that it's a balance I continue to work at, day by day.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Nathan Meyer: In terms of my health, I would say I've been fortunate to maintain a relatively good level of physical and mental well-being, though it hasn't always been easy. Growing up in a family that valued education and intellectual engagement, I wasn't always encouraged to prioritize my physical health in the same way. I remember being more focused on books and debates than on exercise, which led to some habits that I've had to work on over the years. In my early twenties, I started noticing the effects of a sedentary lifestyle—chronic fatigue, occasional back pain, and a general sense of being out of sync with my body. That was when I made a conscious decision to change. I started incorporating regular exercise into my routine, first with running and later with yoga, which has helped me manage stress and stay grounded. I also pay close attention to my diet, making an effort to eat whole foods and limit processed meals, though I'll admit I'm not perfect about it. Mentally, I've always been someone who processes a lot internally, and there were times when I struggled with anxiety, especially when I was first adjusting to life in the U.S. and dealing with the pressures of graduate school. Over time, I've learned to lean on my support systems—friends, family, and even therapy—to help me navigate those moments. I think the key for me has been balance: finding ways to take care of my body and mind without feeling like I'm adding more pressure to an already demanding life. It's an ongoing process, but one I take seriously because I know how much my health affects my ability to do the work I care about and be present for the people I love.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Nathan Meyer: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that integrates movement and mindfulness into my daily life. Whether it's a morning run, a yoga session, or even a short walk during my lunch break, these small acts of self-care help me feel more centered. I also find that cooking at home and eating mindfully—rather than rushing through meals—has a positive impact on both my physical and mental health. What makes it harder, though, is the constant pressure of my work and the emotional weight that comes with it. There are days when I feel overwhelmed by the challenges I see in the communities I serve, and that can make it harder to prioritize my own well-being. I've had to remind myself that taking care of myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. It's something I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it, especially now that I've started waking up earlier to give myself that quiet time to reflect and breathe.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Nathan Meyer: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some recurring issues related to my back, likely from long hours of sitting at my desk and the stress of my work. A few months ago, I saw a physical therapist who helped me identify some posture issues and recommended a series of exercises to strengthen my core and improve my flexibility. It's been a slow process, but I've noticed a significant improvement in how I feel, especially after incorporating regular stretching into my routine. I also had a mild flare-up of anxiety earlier this year, which I managed through a combination of therapy, mindfulness practices, and leaning on my support network. It was a challenging time, but it reminded me of the importance of taking care of my mental health just as seriously as my physical health. I've learned that even small changes—like taking short breaks throughout the day or practicing deep breathing—can make a big difference in how I show up for myself and for the people I work with.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Nathan Meyer: While my health issues haven't prevented me from working or caring for others, they have certainly shaped how I approach my responsibilities. There were times when the physical discomfort or emotional strain made it harder to focus, and I had to be more intentional about pacing myself. I've learned to recognize when I need to step back, take a break, or seek support—whether that's through therapy, a walk in the park, or simply talking to a friend. It's not always easy to admit when I'm struggling, but I've come to see it as a strength rather than a weakness. In many ways, these challenges have made me more empathetic to the people I work with, especially those who face similar obstacles. I know how it feels to carry a heavy burden, and that understanding helps me be more patient and compassionate in my work. I don't see my health struggles as setbacks—they've become part of the journey, shaping who I am and how I show up for the people and causes I care about.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Nathan Meyer: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of gratitude and reflection. There have been moments of deep fulfillment, especially when I see the impact of the work I do—whether it's helping a newly arrived family find housing or supporting a community initiative that brings people together. At the same time, there have been days when the weight of the challenges we face in our society feels overwhelming. I think the pandemic has left a lasting imprint on all of us, even if we're not talking about it much anymore. I've noticed a shift in how people connect with each other—some have become more isolated, while others have found new ways to build community. For me, it's been a year of re-evaluating what matters most. I've made a conscious effort to be more present, not just in my work but in my relationships and personal life. I've started setting clearer boundaries between my professional and personal time, which has helped me feel more balanced. I've also been more open about my own struggles, both with my health and with the emotional toll of my work. It's not always easy, but I've come to see vulnerability as a strength rather than a weakness. I think the past year has taught me that life is fleeting, and that the most meaningful things are often the ones we take for granted—like a quiet conversation with a friend, a shared meal with family, or simply feeling like I belong in the world I live in.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with the balance I strive to maintain in my life. The changes I've made—waking up earlier, taking more breaks, and unplugging on weekends—have been small but meaningful steps toward prioritizing my well-being. It's become clear to me that staying healthy isn't just about physical fitness or avoiding illness; it's about creating space for reflection, movement, and connection. I've learned that my mental health is just as important as my physical health, and that both require intentional care. The challenges I've faced—whether it's chronic back pain or moments of anxiety—have taught me to be more compassionate with myself and to recognize when I need to slow down. These insights have not only helped me feel more grounded in my daily life, but they've also deepened my understanding of the people I work with, many of whom face similar struggles. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that this journey of self-care is ongoing—one that I'm committed to nurturing, day by day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Nathan Meyer: I think I've experienced moments of anxiety, especially during the early years of adjusting to life here and during the intense periods of graduate school. There were times when the weight of it all—feeling like an outsider, the pressure to succeed, and the emotional labor of my work—would leave me feeling overwhelmed. I remember sitting in my apartment late at night, staring at the walls, wondering if I was making a difference or just going through the motions. But over time, I've learned to recognize those feelings for what they are and to respond to them with care. I've started seeing a therapist, which has been incredibly helpful in navigating these emotions. I've also found solace in the small, grounding rituals I've built into my life—like cooking, reading, or spending time in nature. I don't think of my anxiety as something that defines me, but rather as a part of me that I've learned to listen to and manage. It's not always easy, but I've come to see it as a signal that I need to slow down, breathe, and reconnect with what truly matters.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Nathan Meyer: For my family, the past year has been a mix of adjustment and connection. My parents have been navigating their own changes—my father, now retired, has been traveling more, which has been both exciting and a bit isolating for him at times. He's always been someone who thrives on intellectual engagement, so the shift from a busy academic schedule to more leisurely pursuits has required some adjustment. My mother, on the other hand, has been more grounded, continuing her part-time work and staying involved in community activities. She's always been the one who reminds me of the importance of balance, and I think that's why she's been a steady presence in my life, especially during the more challenging times. My sister, who moved to Tel Aviv, has been dealing with the complexities of living in a different cultural and political environment, and we've had many conversations about identity, belonging, and what it means to feel at home. While we don't see each other often, those calls have become a source of strength for both of us. Overall, I think my family has been holding up well, and I'm grateful for the ways we've supported each other through this year's uncertainties.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Nathan Meyer: For me, religion has always been a source of grounding and meaning, though I wouldn't say it's the central force in my life. Being Jewish is deeply tied to my identity—it's not just about the rituals or the holidays, but about the values of community, justice, and resilience that have been passed down through generations. My family always emphasized the importance of tikkun olam, the idea of repairing the world, and that has shaped how I approach my work in immigrant integration and social equity. I still observe the major Jewish holidays, especially Passover and Yom Kippur, not just as traditions but as moments of reflection on where I come from and what I hope to contribute to the world. That said, I don't adhere strictly to religious doctrine, and I find spirituality in many other forms—whether it's in the quiet moments of nature, the connections I make with others, or the work I do to create a more just society. I think of it as a personal journey, one that continues to evolve as I grow and learn.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Nathan Meyer: I use social media selectively, mostly to stay connected with colleagues in my field and to follow organizations that align with my work in immigrant integration and social policy. I have a LinkedIn profile where I share articles, participate in discussions, and keep in touch with professionals who are doing similar work across the country. I also follow a few Jewish community pages and cultural organizations that highlight stories from the diaspora, which resonates with my own background. Instagram, on the other hand, is more of a personal space for me—mainly to follow artists, photographers, and writers who inspire me. I find that social media can be both a tool for connection and a source of noise, so I try to use it mindfully. I limit my time on these platforms, especially during the workweek, to avoid distraction. That said, I do appreciate the way it can amplify voices that might otherwise go unheard, and I've even used it a few times to share resources or event information with people in our community. It's not a big part of my life, but when used intentionally, it can be a useful way to stay informed and engaged.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Nathan Meyer: I think social media has played a small but meaningful role in my life during tough times, though not in the way many people might expect. I don't often turn to Facebook or Twitter for emotional support, but I do find comfort in the online communities that align with my values—particularly those focused on social justice, immigrant rights, and Jewish culture. There have been moments when I've posted about my work or shared a personal reflection, and the responses I've received—from colleagues, friends, or even strangers—have been deeply affirming. It's not the same as talking to someone in person, but it does remind me that I'm not alone in the struggles I face. That said, I've learned to be selective about what I consume online. There are times when the noise and negativity can be overwhelming, especially when I'm dealing with personal or professional challenges. For me, the most valuable support has always come from real, face-to-face connections—whether it's a conversation with a friend, a call with my parents, or a moment of solidarity with someone I work with. Social media is a tool, and like any tool, it's only as helpful as how you choose to use it.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my understanding of resilience and self-compassion. Over the past two years, dealing with recurring back pain and moments of anxiety has been a reminder that even the most dedicated and driven individuals are not immune to struggle. These experiences have taught me that vulnerability is not a weakness, but a necessary part of growth. I've learned to listen to my body and mind, to slow down when needed, and to seek support without shame. It's also made me more empathetic toward others who face similar challenges, whether in their work, personal lives, or communities. I now see my health not as a barrier, but as an integral part of who I am—a part that requires care, attention, and balance. These insights have not only helped me navigate my own journey, but they've also deepened my commitment to the work I do, reminding me that true impact begins with taking care of oneself so that one can show up fully for others.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Nathan Meyer: In the past year, I've noticed a shift in my emotional landscape—there's been a quieter kind of stress, one that doesn't always roar in my ears but lingers in the background like a low hum. It's the kind of stress that comes from knowing the work I do is important, yet feeling the weight of how much more needs to be done. I've been more aware of my own emotional boundaries, and I've started to lean into practices that help me process what I'm feeling without letting it consume me. For instance, I've taken up journaling more seriously, not just as a way to reflect but as a way to untangle my thoughts. I also find that spending time in nature—whether it's a walk through the park or sitting by the lake near my apartment—helps me reset. I've been practicing mindfulness more, especially during moments when I feel overwhelmed, and I've found that even a few minutes of focused breathing can make a difference. I've also been more open about my feelings with my colleagues and friends, which has created a sense of shared understanding and support. I think the key for me has been learning to sit with the discomfort rather than trying to push it away, and in doing so, I've found a kind of resilience I didn't know I had.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Nathan Meyer: In terms of making ends meet, my monthly budget is pretty structured, though it's always a balancing act. My biggest expenses are rent, which takes up about a third of my income, and groceries, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home. I also have a monthly budget for public transportation, since I don't own a car, and I make sure to set aside money for utilities and internet. Another significant expense is my health insurance, which is important to me given my ongoing physical therapy and mental health care. I also allocate a portion of my income to savings and charitable donations, as I believe in giving back to the community. While I don't have a family in the traditional sense, I do support my parents financially when needed, especially since my father is retired and my mother still works part-time. I've learned to be mindful of my spending, prioritizing what truly matters—whether it's a good book, a meal with friends, or a weekend trip to the lake. It's not always easy, but I find that having a clear budget helps me stay grounded and focused on the things that bring me joy and purpose.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Nathan Meyer: In the past month, my household spending was around $3,200, which is pretty close to my usual monthly budget. The breakdown is mostly the same as it's been for the past year—rent is the largest chunk, about $1,200, and groceries come in at around $600. I also spend about $300 on public transportation and utilities, and another $400 on health insurance and therapy sessions. I try to set aside $300 for savings and charitable donations, which helps me stay grounded in my values. The rest goes toward personal expenses like books, coffee, and the occasional weekend outing. I've been careful with my budget lately, especially with the rising costs of living in Evanston, but I've found that prioritizing what truly matters—whether it's my health, my work, or time with loved ones—helps me stay focused and avoid unnecessary spending. It's not always perfect, but it's a system that works for me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Nathan Meyer: I rent my home. I live in a two-bedroom apartment near the downtown area of Evanston, which is walkable to most of the places I need to be—cafés, the library, and community centers. Renting has always made more sense for me, especially given the flexibility it offers. I don't see myself settling down in one place for the long term in the same way some people do, and I value the ability to be near the heart of the community where most of my work and social connections are. Plus, owning property feels like a bigger commitment than I'm ready for right now, especially with the way the housing market has been shifting. I've been lucky to find a place that's both affordable and comfortable, and I try to make the most of it by keeping it cozy and welcoming—something that reflects the balance I try to maintain in my life.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Nathan Meyer: Over the past year, my bills have had some noticeable fluctuations, especially with the seasons and the timing of certain expenses. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill tends to go up, and I've had to adjust my budget accordingly. I also noticed an increase in my electricity usage during the colder months because I'm using more lights and appliances to stay warm. On the flip side, during the summer, my water bill tends to rise due to more frequent use of the air conditioner and outdoor watering for my small balcony garden. Holidays also bring some changes—around Hanukkah and Passover, I spend a bit more on groceries and specialty items for meals, which adds a few hundred dollars to my monthly expenses. Additionally, there were a couple of months when I had to pay for unexpected repairs on my apartment, like a leak in the bathroom, which added to my maintenance costs. Overall, I've learned to be more flexible with my budget, setting aside a small emergency fund to handle these kinds of surprises. It's not always easy, but I've come to see these fluctuations as part of the rhythm of life here, and I try to stay adaptable without losing sight of what truly matters.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how deeply intertwined my family's experiences and my own emotional well-being have been over the past year. Talking about my parents' adjustments to retirement and my sister's life in Tel Aviv reminded me of how much family, even when geographically distant, continues to shape who I am. It also made me think about how my own struggles with anxiety and physical health are not isolated experiences, but part of a larger human condition that we all navigate in our own ways. Social media, while not a central part of my life, has shown me that even in small ways, it can be a tool for connection and support—especially when used with intention. These reflections have reinforced the importance of staying grounded in both my personal relationships and my mental health, and I'm grateful for the ways my family and community have helped me through this time.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Nathan Meyer: I do save, though not in a traditional way. I have a savings account, but I also practice what I call 'intentional saving'—setting aside a portion of my income each month for specific goals, like travel, professional development, or unexpected expenses. I've found that having clear intentions behind my savings helps me stay motivated and disciplined. For example, I recently set aside money for a trip to Switzerland to visit my grandmother, which I've been looking forward to for years. I also save for workshops or conferences related to my work in immigrant integration, as I believe in continuing to learn and grow in my field. In addition to that, I try to live within my means, which has become more important as the cost of living in Evanston has risen. I think of saving not just as a financial habit, but as a way of planning for the future while staying grounded in the present. It's a balance I'm still learning, but one that feels meaningful to me.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Nathan Meyer: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big purchases like a home, though I'm not entirely against the idea of buying property someday. The truth is, I'm not sure where I'll be in five or ten years, and I want to keep my options open. That said, I do have a small emergency fund that I've been building up, which gives me peace of mind in case of unexpected expenses. I also set aside money for professional development, like attending conferences or taking courses that help me stay current in my field. I think of saving as a way to create stability, not just for my financial future, but for the kind of life I want to lead—one where I can continue doing the work I care about without being held back by uncertainty. It's not about accumulating wealth, but about having the freedom to make choices that align with my values and my sense of purpose.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Nathan Meyer: My occupation is as a policy analyst for the Center for Community Integration, a non-profit organization based in Evanston. In this role, I focus on developing and advocating for policies that support immigrant integration, housing equity, and social inclusion. My work involves a lot of collaboration—meeting with local government officials, community leaders, and grassroots organizations to understand the challenges people face and to design programs that address those needs. One of the most important parts of my job is conducting research and analysis to support policy recommendations, which often involves reviewing data, attending public forums, and engaging with the communities we serve. I also spend a significant amount of time in the field, visiting community centers, attending cultural events, and speaking directly with individuals who have recently arrived in the U.S. These conversations are incredibly valuable—they help me understand the human side of the policies we're trying to shape. I find that the most meaningful part of my work is when I can see the direct impact of our efforts, whether it's helping a family find stable housing or supporting a program that connects immigrants with local resources. It's not always easy work, but it's deeply fulfilling because I know it's making a real difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Nathan Meyer: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though the days can vary depending on the projects we're working on. Mondays are typically the busiest, as that's when we hold our team meetings and review progress on our initiatives. I also tend to work late a few evenings a week, especially when we're preparing reports or coordinating with local officials. What I find most rewarding is that even though the hours can be long, I feel like my work has a real impact. I get to meet people from all walks of life, hear their stories, and be part of something that helps them feel more at home in this country. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel the weight of it all, but I've learned to pace myself and take breaks when I need to. I think the key is finding a balance between being productive and being present—for both my work and my life.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Nathan Meyer: No, I haven't had more than one job or business. My work with the Center for Community Integration has been my primary focus for the past several years, and I've found that it allows me to dedicate myself fully to the causes I care about. That said, I have taken on a few side projects on a limited basis—mostly consulting for local organizations on immigrant integration strategies or speaking at community events about policy reform. These opportunities have been more about sharing knowledge and supporting the work I already do rather than taking on additional responsibilities. I think it's important to stay engaged in multiple ways, but I also know my limits. I've learned that trying to do too much can lead to burnout, and I've made a conscious effort to prioritize quality over quantity in both my professional and personal life. I'm grateful for the work I do, and I find that staying focused on one path allows me to be more present and impactful in the communities I serve.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined in ways I hadn't fully acknowledged before. The past year has been a time of quiet growth, where I've learned to listen more closely to my body and mind, recognizing when I need to slow down and when I need to push forward. My struggles with stress and anxiety have taught me the importance of emotional coping strategies—like journaling, mindfulness, and spending time in nature—while also reminding me that vulnerability is not a weakness but a form of strength. At the same time, managing my monthly budget and understanding the fluctuations in my expenses has given me a deeper appreciation for the balance between financial responsibility and personal fulfillment. It's clear to me now that taking care of my mental health is just as vital as maintaining a stable income, and both are essential to living a life that feels meaningful and grounded. These insights have not only helped me navigate my own challenges but have also deepened my empathy for others who are working through similar struggles in their own ways.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Nathan Meyer: In total, my household income for the past month was around $5,500. That comes from my full-time position at the Center for Community Integration, which pays well enough to cover my expenses while still allowing me some flexibility. I've been careful with my finances, especially with the rising cost of living in Evanston, and I try to set aside a portion of my income for savings and unexpected expenses. While I don't have a family in the traditional sense, I do support my parents when needed, and I've made it a priority to ensure they're comfortable in their retirement. It's not about luxury—it's about stability, and I think I've found a balance that allows me to live with purpose while also being financially responsible. I know it's not the same as having a partner or children, but I've come to see my life as a series of choices that reflect my values, and I'm content with the path I've chosen.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Nathan Meyer: I've been at the Center for Community Integration for about four years now, and it's been a journey of growth both personally and professionally. The benefits of the job are more than just the standard health insurance and paid time off—they include a strong sense of purpose and the opportunity to work alongside people who are deeply committed to making a difference. We have a generous leave policy, including vacation days, sick leave, and even some mental health days, which I've found incredibly valuable, especially given the emotional weight of the work we do. One of the things I appreciate most is the flexibility they offer—whether it's adjusting my schedule to attend a community event or taking time off to recharge. The workplace itself is collaborative and inclusive, with a culture that encourages open dialogue and mutual support. It's not always easy work, but knowing that my efforts contribute to real change in people's lives makes it all worthwhile.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Nathan Meyer: My relationships at work are generally very positive and built on mutual respect and shared purpose. I have a good rapport with my manager, who I'll call Sarah. She's been a mentor to me in many ways, not just in terms of professional development but also in how she approaches her work with empathy and integrity. She leads with a lot of compassion, which I think is essential in our field, given the sensitive nature of the issues we deal with. I feel comfortable approaching her with questions or concerns, and she always takes the time to listen and offer thoughtful feedback. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We come from different backgrounds and have diverse perspectives, which enriches our work. We collaborate closely on projects, and I find that the open communication and willingness to support one another make the workplace feel like a true community. I think that sense of connection is what makes the challenges we face every day more manageable—it reminds me that I'm not alone in this work, and that we're all in it together for the same reason: to create a more inclusive and equitable society.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Nathan Meyer: My work schedule is generally predictable, though there's a fair amount of flexibility depending on the needs of the projects we're working on. Most of my days follow a standard structure—starting around 8:30 a.m. and ending around 5:30 p.m., with some evenings extending a bit longer when we're preparing reports or coordinating with local officials. That said, I appreciate the flexibility that comes with my role. For instance, if I need to attend a community event or meet with a client outside of regular hours, I can usually adjust my schedule accordingly. The organization values work-life balance, and I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed here for so long. I also have the option to work remotely a few days a week, which is helpful when I need to focus on a specific task or when I just need a change of scenery. Overall, I'd describe my job as having a structured yet adaptable rhythm—one that allows me to be productive while still leaving room for the things that matter most to me, like spending time with family, tending to my garden, or simply taking a walk in the neighborhood.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Nathan Meyer: Overall, I feel reasonably secure in my financial situation, though I wouldn't say I'm without its challenges. I've always been someone who values stability, and I think my job at the Center for Community Integration provides that in a way that aligns with my values. I make enough to cover my expenses, save for the future, and still have some room for the things that bring me joy—like a good book, a meal with friends, or a weekend trip to the lake. That said, I'm aware that my financial situation isn't the same as many others I work with, and that awareness keeps me grounded. I've seen people in our community struggle with housing insecurity, food insecurity, and the emotional toll of financial instability, and that reminds me that my own stability is a privilege. I don't take it for granted, and I try to use what I have to support others in ways that matter—whether it's through my work, my charitable contributions, or simply being present for the people I care about. I think the key for me is balance: knowing that I'm not in a position of excess, but also not in a position of desperation. It's a delicate line, but one I'm trying to walk with intention and gratitude.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40, I realize how much my financial stability and emotional well-being are connected to the rhythms of daily life and the choices I make. The fluctuations in my bills—whether due to seasonal changes, holidays, or unexpected repairs—have taught me the importance of adaptability and planning. At the same time, my work schedule, though structured, allows for the flexibility I need to manage both my professional and personal responsibilities. I've come to see my job not just as a source of income, but as a way to contribute meaningfully to the world around me, which in turn gives me a sense of purpose that helps me navigate the challenges of financial management. It's a balance that requires attention, but one that I've learned to appreciate over time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Nathan Meyer: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles evolved over time. My father was a professor of history at a university in Zurich, and he continued his academic work even after we moved to the U.S. He eventually took a position at a university here, which allowed him to maintain a stable income while also adapting to our new life. My mother, on the other hand, was a linguist and worked as a consultant in language education. She always emphasized the importance of language and communication, not just in her work but in our family life as well. Even after she started working part-time in the U.S., she made sure to stay engaged in her field, which I think helped her feel grounded during our transition. I remember how much they both sacrificed to provide for our family and to support my education. Their work wasn't just about earning a living—it was about creating a foundation for me to explore my own interests and build a life that honored both my heritage and my new home.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Nathan Meyer: My father's job was as a historian, and he spent much of his career researching and teaching European history, with a particular focus on the 19th and 20th centuries. He was a professor at the University of Zurich, and his work often involved writing academic papers, leading seminars, and mentoring graduate students. Even after we moved to the U.S., he continued his research and eventually took a teaching position at a university here, which allowed him to stay connected to his field. He was deeply passionate about his work, and I remember how he would spend long hours in his study, surrounded by books and maps, trying to piece together the stories of the past. His most important duties were not just teaching, but also inspiring students to think critically about history and its relevance to the present. My mother, on the other hand, was a linguist who specialized in language acquisition and multilingual education. She worked as a consultant, helping schools and organizations develop language programs for immigrants and students learning English as a second language. Her most important activities involved designing curricula, conducting workshops, and working closely with teachers to ensure that language education was accessible and effective. She always believed that language was more than just words—it was a bridge between cultures, and she made it her mission to help others cross that bridge. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for our family, and I think that balance between their professional lives and their personal lives is something I've carried with me throughout my own journey.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Nathan Meyer: My father worked for a university, first in Zurich and later here in the U.S., and my mother worked as an independent consultant in language education. Their work was more about intellectual engagement than manufacturing or services—my father was always writing, teaching, and researching, while my mother was designing programs, running workshops, and advising schools on how to better support multilingual students. They didn't make huge amounts of money, but they were always financially stable, which allowed my siblings and me to focus on our education and personal growth. I remember my father often saying that his work was about understanding the past to better navigate the present, and my mother believed that language was the key to connection. Their jobs weren't just about earning a paycheck—they were about making a difference in the lives of others, whether through history or through education. That's something I think I inherited from them, even if my path ended up being different.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Nathan Meyer: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue the work I'm doing now, but with a deeper sense of impact and connection. I'd like to see more tangible progress in the policies we're advocating for—whether it's better access to housing for newly arrived immigrants, stronger protections for marginalized communities, or more inclusive education programs that help people feel seen and valued. I also hope to have more time to travel, especially back to Switzerland to visit my grandmother and explore the places that shaped my childhood. I imagine myself still living in Evanston, but maybe with a bit more space—perhaps a small home with a garden where I can grow more than just herbs. I'd like to continue learning, maybe through more formal education or mentorship, and to build stronger relationships with the people I work with, turning colleagues into lifelong friends. Most of all, I hope to feel more at peace with the journey I'm on, knowing that I've stayed true to the values that matter most: compassion, inclusion, and the belief that everyone deserves a chance to belong.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Nathan Meyer: What I value the most in my life is connection—both to people and to the world around me. It's the conversations I have with friends, the moments I share with my family, and the relationships I build with the people I work with that give my life meaning. I also value authenticity—the ability to be true to myself, to my heritage, and to the values that have shaped me. I think it's easy to get caught up in the noise of everyday life, but what keeps me grounded is the sense of purpose I feel when I'm working to create a more inclusive and just society. I value learning, whether it's through books, conversations, or new experiences, and I believe that growth is a lifelong journey. Most of all, I value the quiet moments—the ones where I can sit with a cup of coffee, listen to the sounds of the neighborhood, or simply be present without distraction. Those are the moments that remind me why I do what I do, and they're what I hope to carry with me no matter where life takes me next.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, I realize how much my financial stability and the structure of my work have shaped my sense of security and purpose. Discussing my monthly income, expenses, and the flexibility of my job has reminded me of the balance I strive for in my life—between responsibility and freedom, between earning a living and living with intention. Knowing that I can cover my bills, save for the future, and still have time for the things that matter most gives me a sense of peace. At the same time, the relationships I've built at work—especially with my manager and coworkers—have reinforced how important it is to feel supported and connected in what can sometimes be emotionally heavy work. I've come to see my job not just as a means to an end, but as a space where I can contribute meaningfully to the world while also nurturing the relationships that keep me grounded. It's a balance I'm still learning, but one that feels deeply fulfilling.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and connection—not just to my past, but to the people, places, and values that have shaped me. It's amazing how much of my identity is rooted in the moments of uncertainty, the support I received from my family and mentors, and the conscious choices I've made along the way. From my early years in Zurich to my life in Evanston, I've always been navigating the balance between belonging and self-discovery, between my Swiss and American roots, and between my career and personal life. This interview has reminded me how deeply interconnected these aspects of my life are, and how much I owe to the people who believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself. It's also been a chance to reflect on my health, my financial stability, my work, and my relationships, and to see how they all contribute to the life I've built. I'm grateful for the journey I've had, and I'm hopeful for the future, knowing that I've always been guided by a sense of purpose, connection, and the belief that everyone deserves a place where they belong.
